Thread hh/9

Csaba Hoch "r" tag for revised posts [hh-conventions, prop, reviewed] <hh/9> <root> (2009-03-08) 
I think in order to make it easier to keep this heap tidy, we
should use a tag that states "this post has been revised". It
should be short, so I started using the [r] tag.
Attila Nagy — <hh/25> <↑hh/9> (2009-03-19) 
Sorry, I don't quite get it. What do you mean by revising?
Csaba Hoch — <hh/27> <↑hh/25> (2009-03-20) 
When a human maintainer of the heap reads (revises) the post and makes
the changes that should be done, the post can be considered as
revised. Maybe "review" is a better word?
Attila Nagy — <hh/29> <↑hh/27> (2009-03-20) 
How would this be related to the proposal that we should always
respond to proposals? (I mean the obligatory answer that can be a
simple OK too.)
Csaba Hoch — <hh/30> <↑hh/29> (2009-03-21) 
Not at all.
Csaba Hoch — <hh/31> <↑hh/30> (2009-03-21) 
>> How would this be related to the proposal that we should always
>> respond to proposals? (I mean the obligatory answer that can be a
>> simple OK too.)
>
> Not at all.

== "OK" responses ==

An "OK" post means that you, as a Hh user (and probably Hm developer)
agree with a proposal (or at least you don't have any objections that
are worth mentioning). The proposal usually has its own thread. The
"OK" convention is related only to Hh, not other heaps.

== [r] ==

If you are a heap maintainer, you would add [r] to a post when you
think that it is OK. (E.g. it does not contain meta-commands to be
executed). It would help the maintenance of a heap, because this way
a maintainer's work could described as this:
1. Download the new posts.
2. Read through the posts without [r] tag. (Mostly they will be new
   posts I guess, but not necessarily.) If they need some change,
   change them.
3. Add [r] tag to the posts that are OK. (If you had time to finish
   with all posts (without [r]), then you should add [r] for all of
   them.)
4. The work is finished for today. You don't need to care about posts
   with [r], as they have been already reviewed by either you or
   another maintainer in the past.

The [r] tag would go individually to the posts. This convention makes
sense for all heaps.
Attila Nagy — <hh/42> <↑hh/31> (2009-03-23) 
Do you think we can be certain that a given post or thread is "OK", so
that it needs no further editing? (This is not a rhetorical question,
"yes" is a perfectly acceptable answer.)
Csaba Hoch — <hh/43> <↑hh/42> (2009-03-23) 
> Do you think we can be certain that a given post or thread is "OK", so
> that it needs no further editing? (This is not a rhetorical question,
> "yes" is a perfectly acceptable answer.)

I don't say it is sure that it does not need any futher editing; it
say that the maintainer currently doesn't see anything that should be
done. It is like commiting your code or pushing it to github: you
don't say it doesn't have to be rewritten ever, but the fact that you
commited it means that you think it reached a certanin quality.
Attila Nagy — <hh/44> <↑hh/43> (2009-03-23) 
Then a better idea would be a header entry, which could also contain a
date, like:

    Last-Revised: 2009-03-23 17:03

The [r] doesn't say anything on when was the post deemed acceptable.
Attila Nagy — <hh/45> <↑hh/44> (2009-03-23) 
> The [r] doesn't say anything on when was the post deemed acceptable.

However, you could do a git-blame on the "Tag: r" line.
Csaba Hoch — <hh/46> <↑hh/44> (2009-03-23) 
> Then a better idea would be a header entry, which could also contain a
> date, like:
>
>    Last-Revised: 2009-03-23 17:03
>
> The [r] doesn't say anything on when was the post deemed acceptable.

I don't think you see in what way I want to use the [r] tag. I don't
care about when the post was reviewed. I only care about the fact that
it was reviewed once, it does not contain todo-s, and it does not
involve any further work to do. It would make the work of the
maintainers much easier.

We could add a date for the revision, but I don't see any point in
that. If you think there is a use for that, I'm eager to read about
it.
Attila Nagy — <hh/47> <↑hh/46> (2009-03-23) 
[close]

> I only care about the fact that it was reviewed once, it does not
> contain todo-s, and it does not involve any further work to do.

Hmm. Maybe you have a point there. OK, I agree then.
